DOC.HEAD: Carrollton Bus Crash Prompts Tougher Bus-Safety Regulations
With PM-Bus Crash Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The nation's worst drunken-driving disaster has prompted federal and state officials nationwide to work to make school buses safer. Kentucky, in particular, has approved new safety standards for future school buses and is poised to toughen its drunken driving laws after the fiery bus crash that killed 27 people, including 24 children. The crash happened when a church bus collided with a pickup traveling the wrong way on Interstate 71 near Carrollton, Ky. A jury on Thursday convicted the pickup's driver, Larry Mahoney, of 27 counts of second-degree manslaughter. The former school bus, owned by the First of Assembly of God Church in Radcliff, Ky., burst into flames upon impact. Defense lawyers contended that safety defects in the 1977 bus caused the loss of more lives. Investigators said the victims were trapped inside the bus with only one working exit and were overcome by smoke from a fire that spread among highly flammable seats. The magnitude of the tragedy, exacerbated by its young victims' ages, has drawn attention from all parts of the United States. ``There's been a lot of changes as a result of the Carrollton accident than anything else we've seen,'' said Don Carnahan, director of pupils' transportation in Washington state. Since the May 14, 1988, crash, officials at all levels of government have taken steps to add emergency exits, install less flammable materials, reconsider the location of the gas tank on buses and restrict the use of older buses. Across the country, school officials, government regulators and bus manufacturers say the crash has torpedoed a decade of confidence in the safety of school buses _ confidence dating back to the last extensive changes in federal regulations in 1977. The crash ``has caused more dialogue within the industry than any other accident in recent history,'' said Ray Kroll, director of transportation for Minneapolis schools and president of the National Association for Pupil Transportation. In Kentucky, the state school board approved new safety regulations in July for new school buses that will require them to have roof-escape hatches, fire resistant interiors and a wider space by the emergency exit. Those were among some of the recommendations made by the National Transportation Safety Board after it concluded an investigation of the bus crash. The board also urged the state to enact stricter laws for driving under the influence. In its final report, the board praised the work of a task force on drunken driving appointed by Gov. Wallace Wilkinson. Among the task force recommendations was proposed legislation that would make it an offense for any driver to test above a 0.10 level on a blood alcohol level. Current law presumes that a driver is intoxicated if they have a test at that level. A state attorney general's task force later recommended the state lower the blood-alcohol level at which a person would be considered legally drunk. Both proposals, among numerous others, will be dealt with when the state Legislature convenes in January.
